paper.title: Phase-curve Evidence for an Atmosphere on TRAPPIST-1 b

core_question: Does JWST phase-curve and spectroscopy data for TRAPPIST-1 b support a real atmosphere versus a bare-rock no-atmosphere interpretation?

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Observed system
datasets_or_cohorts.sample_size_or_observations: One rocky exoplanet with phase-resolved thermal spectra
datasets_or_cohorts.description: The study focused on TRAPPIST-1 b using JWST MIRI phase-curve spectroscopy to measure thermal variation and spectral structure.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: No-atmosphere baseline
datasets_or_cohorts.description: A bare-rock, no-atmosphere model with minimal heat redistribution was evaluated against the observations as a null scenario.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: CO2-rich atmosphere model
datasets_or_cohorts.description: An atmosphere-bearing retrieval family with significant CO2 absorption was tested to explain phase-curve and 15 um spectral behavior.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: O2-rich atmosphere model
datasets_or_cohorts.description: An oxidized O2-rich composition was also modeled and found not to be fully excluded by current data.

major_limitations: Single-planet evidence does not establish atmospheric prevalence across all M-dwarf rocky planets.
Model assumptions on circulation, opacity priors, and cloud treatment can significantly affect quantitative posteriors.
Stellar variability and instrument systematics may bias weak spectral features, while night-side constraints are weaker than day-side constraints.
